message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperprolactinemia, which can cause amenorrhea and nipple discharge. Dopamine agonists can inhibit the secretion of prolactin and treat hyperprolactinemia. Somatostatin is used to treat acromegaly, Cushing's disease, and some types of tumors. Vasopressin is used to treat diabetes insipidus. Insulin is used to treat diabetes mellitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient may have hyperprolactinemia, a condition in which there is an excess of prolactin in the blood. Dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine or cabergoline are the mainstay of treatment for hyperprolactinemia. Somatostatin analogs can also be used but they are less effective than dopamine agonists. Vasopressin and insulin have no relation to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Amenorrhea and nipple discharge suggest hyperprolactinemia, which is treated with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine or cabergoline. None of the other options are related to hyperprolactinemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of amenorrhea and nipple discharge suggest a possible pituitary tumor called prolactinoma, which can be treated with dopamine receptor agonists. Somatostatin is used to treat acromegaly, Vasopressin is used to treat diabetes insipidus, and Insulin is used for diabetes mellitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperprolactinemia, and dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine are used to treat this condition. Somatostatin agonists are used to treat acromegaly, vasopressin agonists are used to treat diabetes insipidus, and insulin is used to treat diabetes mellitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest hyperprolactinemia, which can cause amenorrhea and nipple discharge. Dopamine receptor agonists are used to treat hyperprolactinemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The amenorrhea and white nipple discharge suggests hyperprolactinemia. Among the options, dopamine receptor agonist can help reduce prolactin levels and treat the condition. Somatostatin analogs can also help reduce prolactin levels, but dopamine agonists are more commonly used. Vasopressin and insulin are not related to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient may have a prolactinoma, which can cause amenorrhea and nipple discharge. Dopamine agonists are the first-line treatment for prolactinomas as they inhibit secretion of prolactin, which is responsible for these symptoms. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Dopamine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history suggests she may have hyperprolactinemia, which can cause amenorrhea and galactorrhea (white nipple discharge). Dopamine agonists, such as bromocriptine or cabergoline, are used to treat hyperprolactinemia. Somatostatin analogues are used for treatment of acromegaly and certain tumors, vasopressin agonists are used for treating diabetes insipidus, and insulin is used for diabetes mellitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Amenorrhea and nipple discharge suggest hyperprolactinemia, which is treated with dopamine agonists. Among the options, dopamine is the neurotransmitter that regulates prolactin secretion.
